newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: PM SAYS 30 PERCENT OF POPULATION PAYS NO TAXES.
newsitem.headline: PM SAYS 30 PERCENT OF POPULATION PAYS NO TAXES.

text.p: Lithuanian Prime Minister Gediminas Vagnorius said on Thursday that 30 percent of the country's working population was paying no income taxes.
"The statistics are very sad, only 1.25 million people pay income taxes compared to 1.9 million people a few years ago," Vagnorius told a news conference.
"If such a tempo remains, at the end of this year or at the beginning of 1998 the number of working people (paying taxes) would be the same as those on pension," Vagnorius added.
There are around 900,000 pensioners in the country.
Vagnorius said that the government intends to ram a fresh batch of laws through parliament in the next few days which will tighten the noose around tax evaders and force them to pay up.
"We have no other choice but to force the 30 percent who pay no income taxes to pay like the rest of the population," Vagnorius said.
Revenue collection has improved since the government launched a campaign early in the year against companies who dodged their tax obligations.
The state budget posted a surplus for the first four months of 1997, the first time it was in the black in this period since 1992.
